FuncDef:
The dhcp ip-ttl command sets the Time to Live (TLL) value of DHCP response packets.
The undo dhcp ip-ttl command clears the configuration on the TTL value of DHCP response packets.
By default, when the device functions as a DHCP server or DHCP Relay, if the response packets are broadcast packets, the TTL value is set to 1. If the response packets are unicast packets, the response packets are processed based on the TTL value encapsulated in the response packets, and therefore there is no fixed default value.

ParaDef.Info:
TTL value of DHCP response packets, that is, the value of the Time to Live field in the IP headers.
The value is an integer ranging from 1 to 255.

ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
You can set a TTL value as required using the dhcp ip-ttl command. The DHCP server or DHCP Relay will send DHCP response packets based on the TTL value. When the device functions as a DHCP server or DHCP Relay, if the response packets are broadcast packets, the TTL default value is set to 1. If the response packets are unicast packets, the response packets are processed based on the TTL value encapsulated in the response packets, and therefore there is no fixed default value.
If you run the dhcp ip-ttl ttl-value command to configure a TTL value, the configured TTL value takes effect.
Precautions
In VS mode, this command is supported only by the admin VS.
